title: How to Build a Straw Bale Compost Bin

steps.headline: Place the bin in an area that gets direct sunlight.
steps.description: This will encourage decomposition. As the bin and its contents decompose, it will sag over time. For this reason, you might want to place your bin out of the way where it won’t be an eyesore. Additionally, you should not place the bin on couch grass because the grass will grow into the straw bale and make it difficult to remove. If you intend to garden directly on the soil of your straw bale compost bin, place it in a location where you want your future garden to grow.

steps.headline: Protect your bales with weed mats or cardboard boxes.
steps.description: A weed mat is a barrier that prevents the growth of grass and weeds. Lay down a weed mat or a cardboard box beneath the area where you want to place the straw bales. This will prevent weeds from growing into them. If weeds grow into your straw bales, they will quickly multiply and contaminate the composting mass itself. You can obtain weed mats at your local gardening shop.

steps.headline: Create a three-sided bin for easy access.
steps.description: The simplest bin will have three sides. A bin with four sides will better insulate the compost pile, but one side will need to be moved aside when you want to turn the earth in the center of the pile.

steps.headline: Don’t stack your bin more than two bales high.
steps.description: Two bales is enough to contain a reasonable quantity of compostable material. However, the smallest bins will be only one bale high. A bin that is two bales high can contain more compostable material, but it will also take longer to decompose everything than a bin that is only one bale high. If you add straw bales, don’t stack them directly over the bales below. Instead, stagger them so that the upper bale lays equally across two lower bales, crossing the corner between them.

steps.headline: Ask a friend for help if you need it.
steps.description: Straw bales can be heavy. If you find that you need assistance lifting and transporting them, ask a friend or family member for help. Straw bales are heavier when wet. Move them when they’re dry. You can obtain straw bales from your local farming supply company. Straw bales come in a range of sizes. The best bales for creating a straw bale compost bin are “two-string" bales 18 inches (45.7 cm) (460 mm) wide, by either 14 or 16 inches (35.6 or 40.6 cm) (350 to 400 mm) high, and 32 to 48 inches (81.3 to 122 cm) (0.8 to 1.2 m) long.

steps.headline: Fill the bin with waste.
steps.description: Toss uncooked produce scraps into the bin. Grass clippings, garden clippings, egg shells, leaves, twigs, and pine needles will also easily compost.

steps.headline: Cover the pile with black plastic.
steps.description: Once you’ve filled the bin, pull a black plastic bag or tarp over it. This will help maintain the necessary internal heat and retain water. The heat will help the compost break down.

steps.headline: Turn the soil if it starts to smell.
steps.description: There’s no one right way to turn the soil. You could dig up some of the earth in the center of the compost pile, then sprinkle it over the rest of the material, or you could hoe it vigorously to stir everything together. The goal is to just get all the composting material mixed together. Smelly compost means there’s not enough oxygen for the compost to break down. If your straw bale compost pile has four sides, just pull one side open to gain access to the center of the pile.

steps.headline: Work the straw into the soil.
steps.description: After four to six months, the compost and your straw will be thoroughly decomposed. Cut through the baling wire holding the straw together. Stir the straw into the rest of the compost pile. Over time, the whole bin will naturally decompose.

steps.headline: Spread the compost material on your garden.
steps.description: Scoop the compost into a wheelbarrow or bag, then spread it on your garden. The nutrient-rich compost will act as a mulch for your plants.

steps.headline: Plant directly in the bin after two to three months.
steps.description: If you don’t want to use the composted soil somewhere else in, just spread it in an even layer on the same spot where it composted and wait another few months. You’ll then have rich, black soil that you can plant in.
